title: Anacacia Capital plants Roots in infrastructure sector
text:
While the terms of the deal are not known, Anacacia typically invests in profitable small to medium sized businesses with at least $20 million revenue.

Anacacia Capital managing director Jeremy Samuel confirmed the investment to Street Talk on Thursday.

"The infrastructure needs in Australia are very high," Samuel said. "Our due diligence illustrated that government and asset owners are increasingly looking to engage Root Partnerships to manage the quality and costs of such large investments."

"We are excited to back Root Partnerships in the next part of their growth journey."

Root Partnerships' Peter Root is expected to continue as the company's managing director following Anacacia's investment, while long-time director David Grundy will be chief executive officer and Mac Lydiard was tapped as chief operating officer.

Samuel said Anacacia still had "a lot of capital to deploy" following a $300 million fundraising last year raised in double-quick time, with capital stemming from local and offshore funds and family offices.

The investment caps a big few weeks for Anacacia. It was named as firm of the year at the annual Australian Investment Council awards last month and won the best small cap investment for its stake in dips and hummus maker Yumi's Quality Foods.

Anacacia, which is perhaps best known for its early backing of $2.7 billion technology company Appen, was founded in 2007 by Jeremy Samuel and invests in listed and unlisted companies, typically with annual revenue worth $20 million to $200 million and at least $5 million profit.
description: Australian private equity firm Anacacia Capital is seeking a slice of the $288 billion infrastructure pipeline.
